[[Chicago blues]] | occupation = [[Pianist]], [[singer]] | years_active = 1920s–2011 | label = [[Blind Pig Records]] | associated_acts = | website = [http://www.pinetopperkins.com/ Pinetop Perkins.com] | notable_instruments = }} '''Joseph William Perkins''' (July 7, 1913 – March 21, 2011), known by the stage name '''Pinetop Perkins''', was an American [[blues piano|blues pianist]]. Perkins played with some of the most influential blues and [[rock and roll]] performers in American history and received numerous honors during his lifetime, including a [[Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award]] and induction into the [[Blues Hall of Fame]]. ==Life and career== ===Early career=== Perkins was born in [[Belzoni, Mississippi]].[http://www.imdb.com/name/nm0674031/bio IMDb database birth information] He began his career as a [[guitarist]], but then injured the [[tendon]]s in his left arm in a fight with a chorus girl in [[Helena, Arkansas]].{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/pinetop-perkins-mn0000349439/biography|title=Pinetop Perkins|last=Dahl|first=Bill|publisher=Allmusic|accessdate=2014-01-26}} Unable to play [[guitar]], Perkins switched to the [[piano]], and also switched from [[Robert Lee McCollum|Robert Nighthawk]]'s [[KFFA (AM)|KFFA]] [[radio]] program to [[Sonny Boy Williamson II|Sonny Boy Williamson]]'s ''[[King Biscuit Time]]''.{{cite book| first= Tony| last= Russell| year= 1997| title= The Blues - From [[Robert Johnson (musician)|Robert Johnson]] to [[Robert Cray]] | publisher=Carlton Books Limited| location= Dubai| isbn= 1-85868-255-X| page= 154}} He continued working with Nighthawk, however, accompanying him on 1950's "Jackson Town Gal". In the 1950s, Perkins joined [[Earl Hooker]] and began touring. He [[sound recording and reproduction|recorded]] "Pinetop's Boogie Woogie" (written by [[Pinetop Smith]]) at [[Sam Phillips]]' studio in [[Memphis, Tennessee]]. ("They used to call me Pinetop," he recalled, "because I played that song.")[http://www.nea.gov/honors/heritage/Heritage00/Perkins.html Joe Willie "Pinetop" Perkins], 2000 [[National Endowment for the Arts|NEA]] [[National Heritage Fellowship]]s However, Perkins was only 15 years old in 1928, when Smith originally recorded "Pinetop's Boogie Woogie". Perkins then relocated to [[Illinois]] and left the music business until Hooker convinced him to record again in 1968. Perkins replaced [[Otis Spann]] when he left the [[Muddy Waters]] band in 1969. After ten years with that organization, he formed [[The Legendary Blues Band]] with [[Willie "Big Eyes" Smith]], recording through the late 1970s, 1980s and early 1990s. ===Later career=== Perkins played a brief musical cameo on the street outside Aretha's Soul Food Cafe in the 1980 movie ''[[The Blues Brothers (film)|The Blues Brothers]]'', having an argument with [[John Lee Hooker]] over who wrote "[[Boom Boom (John Lee Hooker song)|Boom Boom]]." He also appeared in the 1987 movie ''[[Angel Heart]]'' as a member of guitarist Toots Sweet's band. Although he appeared as a [[sideman]] on countless recordings, Perkins never had an album devoted solely to his artistry, until the release of ''[[After Hours (Pintop Perkins album)|After Hours]]'' on [[Blind Pig Records]] in 1988.{{cite web|author=Blind Pig Records |url=http://www.blindpigrecords.com/index.cfm?section=artists&artistid=44 |title=Blind Pig Records |publisher=Blind Pig Records |date= |accessdate=2011-03-22}} The tour in support of the album also featured [[Jimmy Rogers]] and guitarist [[Hubert Sumlin]]. In 1998 Perkins released the [[album]] ''Legends'' featuring Sumlin. Perkins was driving his automobile in 2004 in [[La Porte, Indiana]] when he was hit by a train. The car was wrecked but the 91-year-old driver was not seriously hurt. Until his death, Perkins lived in [[Austin, Texas]]. He usually performed a couple of nights a week at Nuno's on Sixth Street. In 2005, Perkins received the [[Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award]]. In 2008, Perkins received a [[Grammy Award for Best Traditional Blues Album]] for ''[[Last of the Great Mississippi Delta Bluesmen: Live In Dallas]]'' together with [[Henry Townsend (musician)|Henry James Townsend]], [[Robert Lockwood, Jr.]] and [[David Honeyboy Edwards]]. He was also [[nominate]]d in the same category for his solo album, ''Pinetop Perkins on the 88's: Live in Chicago''. The song "Hey Mr. Pinetop Perkins", performed by Perkins and [[Angela Strehli]], played on the common misconception that Perkins wrote "Pinetop's Boogie Woogie": ::''Hey Mr. Pinetop Perkins'' ::''I got a question for you'' ::''How'd you write that first boogie woogie'' ::''The one they named after you'' ===Oldest-ever Grammy winner=== At the age of 97, he won a [[Grammy Award]] for [[Best Traditional Blues Album]] for ''Joined at the Hip'', an album he recorded with [[Willie "Big Eyes" Smith]]. Perkins thus became the oldest-ever Grammy winner,{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-12814133 |title=BBC News - Blues pianist Pinetop Perkins dies aged 97 |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date= March 22, 2011|accessdate=2011-03-22}} edging out comedian [[George Burns]] who had won in the spoken word category 21 years earlier (Perkins had tied with Burns, at the age of 90, in 2004).{{cite web|url=http://www.1310news.com/entertainment/article/183805--blues-pianist-pinetop-perkins-becomes-oldest-grammy-winner-with-award-for-joined-at-the-hip |title=Blues pianist Pinetop Perkins becomes oldest Grammy winner with award for 'Joined at the Hip' |publisher=1310 News|date=2011-02-14|accessdate=2011-04-09}} A little more than a month later, Perkins died on 21 March 2011 at his home in [[Austin, Texas|Austin]]. At the time of his death, the musician had more than 20 performances booked for 2011. Shortly before that, while discussing his late career resurgence with an interviewer, he conceded, "I can't play piano like I used to either. I used to have bass rolling like thunder. I can't do that no more. But I ask the Lord, please forgive me for the stuff I done trying to make a nickel."{{Citation needed|date=November 2011|date=November 2011}} Along with [[David Honeyboy Edwards|David "Honeyboy" Edwards]], he was one of the last two original [[Mississippi Delta|Mississippi]] [[Delta blues]] musicians, and also to have a personal knowledge of, and friendship with, [[Robert Johnson (musician)|Robert Johnson]].[http://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/music-news/8397463/B.B-King-leads-tributes-to-Pinetop-Perkins.html B.B King leads tributes to Pinetop Perkins] ==Selected discography== * 1976: ''Boogie Woogie King'' (recorded 1976, released 1992) * 1977: ''Hard Again'' ([[Muddy Waters]]) * 1988: ''[[After Hours (Pinetop Perkins album)|After Hours]]'' * 1992: ''Pinetop Perkins with the Blue Ice Band * 1992: ''On Top'' * 1993: ''Portrait of a Delta Bluesman'' * 1995: ''Live Top'' (with the Blue Flames) * 1996: ''Eye to Eye'' (with [[Ronnie Earl]], [[Willie "Big Eyes" Smith]] and [[Calvin "Fuzz" Jones]]){{cite web |url=http://www.valley-entertainment.com/eye-to-eye-1.html |title=Eye to Eye |work=Valley Entertainment-Sledgehammer Blues |accessdate=8 July 2010}} * 1997: ''[[Born in the Delta]]'' * 1998: ''[[Sweet Black Angel (album)|Sweet Black Angel]]'' * 1998: ''Legends'' (with [[Hubert Sumlin]]) * 1998: ''Down In Mississippi'' * 1999: ''Live at 85!''
